titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Myron Eells collection

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-10-03.
profiledesc.descrules: Finding aid based on DACS (Describing Archives: A Content Standard), 2nd Edition.

physdesc.extent: 2 flat boxes, 13 record cartons, 48 manuscript boxes

did.abstract: The Myrons Eells collection contains articles, books, manuscripts, and correspondence. This extensive collection, which spans from 1848 to 1998, also consists of speeches, sermons, scrapbooks and other ephemera created or collected by Myron Eells.

bioghist.p: Born in Spokane County, in 1843, Reverend Eells lived in the Willamette Valley, graduated from Pacific University and Hartford Theological Seminary and became ordained in the Congregational Church. He returned to the northwest and spent most of his years in the Puget Sound region as a missionary to the tribes and white settlers until his death in 1907.

scopecontent.p: The Myron Eells Collection contains articles, books, and manuscripts. This collection, which dates from 1848 through 1998, also consists of correspondence, speeches and sermons. There is also a series of six scrapbooks, "The Indians of Puget Sound," which contain drawings, photographs and detailed descriptions of Eells' version of the life and culture of those with whom he worked and lived. This collection also includes travel journals, census reports, books and pamphlets in Pacific Northwest Indian languages, and the Eells family Bible.
